newsitem.title: USA: Computer failures seen likely in year 2000.
newsitem.headline: Computer failures seen likely in year 2000.

text.p: Some U.S. government computer systems failures are likely when the year 2000 begins, a congressional investigator warned on Monday.

"I think there is a high probablity that there will be some failures," Joel Willemssen, the General Accounting Office's director of information resources management, told a House of Representatives Government Reform Committee hearing. The GAO is the congressional investigating agency.
He said the problem would occur when the date changes from Dec. 31, 1999 to Jan. 1, 2000. Many computers that only use the last two digits of a year will read the date as 1900.

"Every government program that provides benefits in any way is subject to these problems, from Social Security and veterans' benefits to student loans and subsidized housing. This is not simply a government issue, it is something that will touch us all," he said.

Willemssen said the problem could be corrected but would need major action by all departments and agencies because the government uses a wide variety of computer systems, many with computer languages that are old or obsolete. "It will take long, hard effort, but it can and must be done," he said.

Keith Rhodes of the GAO said some problems were already happening. He said a three-year defense contract awarded last month for completion in January, 2000 caused a computer to issue a 97-year deliquency notice to the contractor.

Rep. Steve Horn, a California Republican, who chaired the hearing, said all federal agencies now realized there was a problem. "The bad news is that only a few of them have specific, realistic plans to solve the problem before the stroke of midnight on the last day of 1999," he said.

Emmett Paige, the Pentagon's chief information officer, said the Defense Department was moving aggressively to solve the problem at a cost of $1.1 billion. "You can be confident that DOD will get the job done," he said.

John Callahan, assistant secretary of the Health and Human Services Department, which issues checks for Social Security and other programs, said the problem was serious but manageable. "Year 2000 is a departmental priority," he said.
Republican Rep. Tom Davis of Virginia said progress was being made, but expressed concern about a timetable released by the Office of Management and Budget for resolving the problem.
"Many agencies will not be fully prepared, according to the report, until late 1999 and this leaves little time to correct a problem should anything go wrong," he said.
